segment.source: Planning Isolation Groups for the Zones (Windows 10)
segment.target: Planning Isolation Groups for the Zones (Windows 10)

segment.source: Planning Isolation Groups for the Zones
segment.target: Planning Isolation Groups for the Zones

segment.source: Planning Isolation Groups for the Zones
segment.target: Planning Isolation Groups for the Zones

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview
segment.target: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: Isolation groups in Active Directory are how you implement the various domain and server isolation zones.
segment.target: Isolation groups in Active Directory are how you implement the various domain and server isolation zones.

segment.source: A device is assigned to a zone by adding its device account to the group which represents that zone.
segment.target: A device is assigned to a zone by adding its device account to the group which represents that zone.

segment.source: Caution: Do not add devices to your groups yet.
segment.target: Caution: Do not add devices to your groups yet.

segment.source: If a device is in a group when the GPO is activated then that GPO is applied to the device.
segment.target: If a device is in a group when the GPO is activated then that GPO is applied to the device.

segment.source: If the GPO is one that requires authentication, and the other devices have not yet received their GPOs, the device that uses the new GPO might not be able to communicate with the others.
segment.target: If the GPO is one that requires authentication, and the other devices have not yet received their GPOs, the device that uses the new GPO might not be able to communicate with the others.

segment.source: Universal groups are the best option to use for GPO assignment because they apply to the whole forest and reduce the number of groups that must be managed.
segment.target: Universal groups are the best option to use for GPO assignment because they apply to the whole forest and reduce the number of groups that must be managed.

segment.source: However, if universal groups are unavailable, you can use domain global groups instead.
segment.target: However, if universal groups are unavailable, you can use domain global groups instead.

segment.source: The following table lists typical groups that can be used to manage the domain isolation zones discussed in the Woodgrove Bank example in this guide:
segment.target: The following table lists typical groups that can be used to manage the domain isolation zones discussed in the Woodgrove Bank example in this guide:

segment.source: Group name
segment.target: Group name

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: CG_DOMISO_No_IPsec
segment.target: CG_DOMISO_No_IPsec

segment.source: A universal group of device accounts that do not participate in the IPsec environment.
segment.target: A universal group of device accounts that do not participate in the IPsec environment.

segment.source: Typically consists of infrastructure device accounts that will also be included in exemption lists.
segment.target: Typically consists of infrastructure device accounts that will also be included in exemption lists.

segment.source: This group is used in security group filters to ensure that GPOs with IPsec rules are not applied to group members.
segment.target: This group is used in security group filters to ensure that GPOs with IPsec rules are not applied to group members.

segment.source: CG_DOMISO_IsolatedDomain
segment.target: CG_DOMISO_IsolatedDomain

segment.source: A universal group of device accounts that contains the members of the isolated domain.
segment.target: A universal group of device accounts that contains the members of the isolated domain.

segment.source: During the early days of testing, this group might contain only a very small number of devices.
segment.target: During the early days of testing, this group might contain only a very small number of devices.

segment.source: During production, it might contain the built-in Domain Computers group to ensure that every device in the domain participates.
segment.target: During production, it might contain the built-in Domain Computers group to ensure that every device in the domain participates.

segment.source: Members of this group receive the domain isolation GPO that requires authentication for inbound connections.
segment.target: Members of this group receive the domain isolation GPO that requires authentication for inbound connections.

segment.source: CG_DOMISO_Boundary
segment.target: CG_DOMISO_Boundary

segment.source: A universal group of device accounts that contains the members of the boundary zone.
segment.target: A universal group of device accounts that contains the members of the boundary zone.

segment.source: Members of this group receive a GPO that specifies that authentication is requested, but not required.
segment.target: Members of this group receive a GPO that specifies that authentication is requested, but not required.

segment.source: CG_DOMISO_Encryption
segment.target: CG_DOMISO_Encryption

segment.source: A universal group of device accounts that contains the members of the encryption zone.
segment.target: A universal group of device accounts that contains the members of the encryption zone.

segment.source: Members of this group receive a GPO that specifies that both authentication and encryption are required for all inbound connections.
segment.target: Members of this group receive a GPO that specifies that both authentication and encryption are required for all inbound connections.

segment.source: CG_SRVISO_ServerRole
segment.target: CG_SRVISO_ServerRole

segment.source: A universal group of device accounts that contains the members of the server isolation group.
segment.target: A universal group of device accounts that contains the members of the server isolation group.

segment.source: Members of this group receive the server isolation GPO that requires membership in a network access group in order to connect.
segment.target: Members of this group receive the server isolation GPO that requires membership in a network access group in order to connect.

segment.source: There will be one group for each set of servers that have different user and device restriction requirements.
segment.target: There will be one group for each set of servers that have different user and device restriction requirements.

segment.source: Multiple GPOs might be delivered to each group.
segment.target: Multiple GPOs might be delivered to each group.

segment.source: Which one actually becomes applied depends on the security group filters assigned to the GPOs in addition to the results of any WMI filtering assigned to the GPOs.
segment.target: Which one actually becomes applied depends on the security group filters assigned to the GPOs in addition to the results of any WMI filtering assigned to the GPOs.

segment.source: Details of the GPO layout are discussed in the section Planning the GPOs.
segment.target: Details of the GPO layout are discussed in the section Planning the GPOs.

segment.source: If multiple GPOs are assigned to a group, and similar rules are applied, the rule that most specifically matches the network traffic is the one that is used by the device.
segment.target: If multiple GPOs are assigned to a group, and similar rules are applied, the rule that most specifically matches the network traffic is the one that is used by the device.

segment.source: For example, if one IPsec rule says to request authentication for all IP traffic, and a second rule from a different GPO says to require authentication for IP traffic to and from a specific IP address, then the second rule takes precedence because it is more specific.
segment.target: For example, if one IPsec rule says to request authentication for all IP traffic, and a second rule from a different GPO says to require authentication for IP traffic to and from a specific IP address, then the second rule takes precedence because it is more specific.
